Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Distribution Comments: Present on Floreana, Isabela, Santa Cruz and San Cristobal
English Comments: The introduction of this species in the Islands began in 1832 in Floreana, later in San Cristobal (1841), Isabela (1850 aprox.) and in Santa Cruz in 1923.
Spanish Comments: La introduccion de esta especie a las islas comenzo en 1832 en Floreana, luego en San Cristobal (1841), Isabela (1850 aproximadamente) y por ultimo en Santa Cruz en 1923.

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Distribution Comments: San Cristobal, Santa Cruz, and Floreana. Eradicated from Isabela, Baltra, Española, Plaza Sur, Santa Fé, Marchena, Rábida, Santiago, and Pinta. Originally from Asia, Iran.
English Comments: This species had been reported in the Islands since 1685 on most Islands. However goats were also the first eradicated in the Archipelago.
Spanish Comments: Esta especie se registro en las islas desde 1685 y su distribucion en un buen numero de islas. Sin embargo fue una de las primeras especies en su erradicacion.
English Description: Goats are small, hoofed herbivores that can be brown to black to white in color. Goats are very agile and can eat almost anything - leaves, twigs, bark, flowers, fruits and roots.
Spanish Description: Las cabras son herbívoros pequeños que pueden ser de color marrón, negro a blanco; son animales muy ágiles y  pueden comer cualquier cosa - hojas, ramas, cortezas, flores, frutos y raíces.

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Distribution Comments: Unknown, however was present on Santa Cruz, San Cristobal and Isabela
English Comments: Unknown the introduction of this species in the Islands, but the first record was in 1984, and unknown as disappeared.
Spanish Comments: Se desconoce la fecha de introduccion de esta especie en las islas, pero el primer registro fue en 1984. Tambien se desconoce como desaparecio de las islas.

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Distribution Comments: Present on Santa Cruz, San Cristobal, Floreana, Isabela, eradicated on Santiago. Originally from Europe, Continental Asia.
English Comments: This species was introduced in Floreana in 1832, San Cristobal (1835, 1847), Santiago (1875, 1878), Isabela Sur (1897) and in Santa Cruz (1920 aprox.)
Spanish Comments: Esta especie fue introducida en Floreana en 1832, San Cristobal (1835, 1847), Santiago (1875, 1878), Isabela Sur (1897) y en Santa Cruz (1920 aprox.)
English Description: Wild pigs are large mammals which are usually dark in color, with thick hair and a long snout. These pigs can be distinguished from domestic varieties by their lean, muscular body and tusks, as well as a characteristic tuft of coarse hair along the back. Wild pigs are herd animals, and male boars can join a group of 12-15 females during the breeding season, though adult boars are otherwise solitary.
Spanish Description: Los cerdos salvajes son normalmente de color oscuro, con el pelo grueso y un hocico largo. Son animales de manada, con un macho unido a un grupo de 12-15 hembras durante la época de reproducción.

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Distribution Comments: Present on Santa Cruz, San Cristobal, Floreana and Isabela
English Comments: The first record in the Archipelago was on Santiago in 1685. Later was recorded  on Floreana (1832), San Cristóbal (1842, 1847), Isabela (1835, 1868).
Spanish Comments: El primer registro en el Archipielago fue en Santiago en 1685. Posteriormente fue registrado en Floreana 1832, San Cristobal (1842, 1847), Isabela (1835, 1868).
English Description: Domestic dogs are highly variable in shape after thousands of years of human selection to obtain particular characteristics. While domestic dogs are associated with humans, feral domestic dogs are more varied in their behavior, and are often found in groups.
Spanish Description: Los perros son muy variables en su forma después de miles de años de selección humana pra obtener caracteristicas particulares. Mientras que los perros domésticos están asociados con los seres humanos, los perros salvajes son muy variados en su comportamiento, y a menudo se encuentra en grupos. Los perros son principalmente carnívoros, pero comen frutas e invertebrados. Pueden reproducirse hasta dos veces por año a partir de 6 meses de edad con 2-12 cachorros por camada.

Author: (Schreber, 1775)
Distribution Comments: Eradicated on Baltra. Present on Floreana, San Cristobal, Santa Cruz and Isabela.
English Comments: The first recored was in 1832 in Floreana Island. After were in Isabela, San Cristobal and Santa Cruz with the colonization. The intruduction in Baltra, possibly was in the Second War, and the eradicated in 2004.
Spanish Comments: El primer registro fue en 1832 en Floreana. Posteriormente en las otras islas cuando estas fueron colonizadas. La introduccion en Baltra posiblemente fue en la segunda guerra mundial y su erradicacion en 2004.
English Description: The domestic cat is a small solitary carnivore that is primarily nocturnal. Domestic cats hunt for invertebrates and small vertebrates.
Spanish Description: El gato es un pequeño carnívoro solitario, caza sobre todo por la noche, se alimenta de invertebrados y pequeños vertebrados. Las hembras pueden reproducirse en su primer año, con 2 litros de 4 crías por año.

Author: Lacépéde, 1804
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Agaphelus gibbosus Cope, 1968, Balaena gibbosa Cope, 1868, Balaena microcephala Tomilin, 1957, Balaena minima Rapp, 1837, Balaena minima borealis Knox, 1838, Balaena rostrata Fabricius, 1780 , Balaenoptera acutorostrata thalmaha Deraniyagala, 1963, Balaenoptera acuturostrata Lacépède, 1804 (lapsus calami), Balaenoptera davidsoni Scammon, 1872, Balaenoptera eschrichtius Rasch, 1845 , Balaenoptera microcephala Gray, 1850, Balaenoptera rostrata Van Beneden & Gervais, 1880, Balaenoptera thalmaha, Balaenoptera thalmaha thalmaha Deranyagala, 1963, Pterobalaena minor Eschricht, 1849, Pterobalaena minor bergensis Eschricht, 1849, Pterobalaena minor groenlandica Eschricht, 1849, Pterobalaena nana Barkow, 1862, Pterobalaena nana pentadactyla Barkow, 1862 , Pterobalaena nana tetradactyla Barkow, 1862, Pterobalaena pentadactyla Flower, 1865, Rorqualus minor Hamilton, 1837, Sibbaldius mondinii Capellini, 1877, fide Appeltans et al. Author: Lesson, 1828
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Balaenoptera alba Giglioli, 1870 (synonym), Balaenoptera arctica Temminck, 1841 (synonym), Balaenoptera iwasi Gray, 1846 (synonym), Balaenoptera laticeps Gray, 1846 (synonym), Balaenoptera schlegelii Van Beneden & Gervais, 1880 (synonym), Balaenoptera schlegellii Dabbene, 1902 (synonym), Balena rostrata Rudolphi, 1822 (synonym), Belaenoptera schlegeli Lahille, 1899 (synonym), Pterobalaena alba Giglioli, 1874 (synonym), Pterobalaena schlegeli Tomilin, 1957 (synonym), Pterobalaena schlegeli alba Tomilin, 1957 (synonym), Sibbaldius schlegelii Gray, 1864 (synonym), fide Appeltans et al. (2010)

Author: Anderson, 1879
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Balaenoptera brydei Olsen, 1913 (Nomen inquirendum), Baloenoptera brydei Cadenat, 1957, fide Appeltans et al. (2010)

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Balaena borealis Fischer, 1829 (synonym), Balaena maximus, Balaena musculus Linnaeus, 1758 (basionym), Balaenoptera carolinae Malm, 1866 (synonym), Balaenoptera gigas Reinhardt, 1857 (synonym), Balaenoptera indica Blyth, 1859 (synonym), Balaenoptera jubartes Lacépède, 1804 (synonym), Balaenoptera miramaris Lahille, 1898 (synonym), Balaenoptera sibbaldi Van Beneden, 1887 (synonym), Balaenoptera sibbaldii Flower, 1885 (synonym), Physalus latirostris Flower, 1865 (synonym), Physalus sibbaldii Gray, 1847 (synonym), Pterobalaena gigas Reinhardt, 1857 (synonym), Pterobalaena grypus Munter, 1877 (synonym), Rorqualus boops F. Author: (Linnaeus, 1758)

Cuvier, 1836, Rorqualus australis Hamilton, 1837, fide Appeltans et al. (2010)

Author: Gray, 1846
English Common Name: Short finned pilot whale, shortfin pilot whale

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Orcinus glacialis (Berzin & Vladimirov, 1983), Orcinus nanus Mikhalev etal., 1981

Author: Montagu, 1821
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Tursiops gephyreus Lahille, 1908, Tursiops gilli Dall, 1873, Tursiops nuuanu Andrews, 1911

Author: Blainville, 1838
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Cogia breviceps Benham, 1901 (synonym), Euphisetes pottsi Tomilin, 1957 (misspelling), Euphysetes grayii Wall, 1851 (synonym), Euphysetes macleayi Gill, 1871 (synonym), Euphysetes pottsi Haast, 1874 (synonym), Kogia brevirostris Gray, 1865 (synonym), Kogia floweri Gill, 1871 (synonym), Kogia goodei True, 1884 (synonym), Kogia grayi Gill, 1871 (synonym), Kogia greyi Trouessart, 1898 (synonym), Kogia macleayi Gill, 1871 (synonym), Physeter breviceps de Blainville, 1838 (basionym), fide Appeltans et al. (2010)

Author: Blainville, 1871
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Delphinus densirostris Blainville, 1817 (basionym), Nodus densirostris Galbreath, 1963 (synonym), Ziphius sechellensis Gray, 1846 (synonym), fide Appeltans et al. (2010)

Author: Cuvier, 1823
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Aliama desmarestii Gray, 1864, Aliama indica Gray, 1865, Delphinorhynchus australis Burmeister, 1865, Delphinus desmaresti Risso, 1826, Delphinus philippii Cocco, 1846, Epiodon australe Burmeister, 1867, Epiodon australis Gray, 1871, Epiodon chathamiensis Hector, 1873, Epiodon cryptodon Gray, 1870, Epiodon desmarestii Carus, 1893, Epiodon heraultii Gray, 1872, Epiodon patachonicum Burmeister, 1867, Hyperodon semijunctus Cope, 1865, Hyperondon semijunctus Hall & Kelson, 1959, Hyperoodon capensis Gray, 1865, Hyperoodon desmarestii Gray, 1850, Hyperoodon doumetii Gray, 1850, Hyperoodon gervaisii Duvernoy, 1851, Petrorhynchus capensis Gray, 1865, Petrorhynchus indicus Gray, 1865, Petrorhynchus mediterraneus Gray, 1871, Ziphiorrhynchus cryptodon Burmeister, 1865, Ziphius aresques Gray, 1871, Ziphius australis Trouessart, 1904, Ziphius cavirostris indicus Deraniyagala, 1945, Ziphius chatamensis Lahille, 1899, Ziphius chathamensis Flower, 1885, Ziphius chathamiensis Iredale & Troughton, 1934, Ziphius cryptodon Fischer, 1857, Ziphius decavirostris Gray, 1871, Ziphius grebnitzkii Stejneger, 1883, Ziphius indicus Van Beneden, 1863, Ziphius novaezealandiae Haast, 1876, Ziphius savii Richiardi, 1873, Zyphius chathamensis Moreno, 1895, fide Appeltans et al. (2010)

Author: (Müller, 1776)
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Lasiurus borealis Müller, 1776, Atalapha brachyotis Peters, 1871, Nycteris borealis Borkhausen, 1797
Distribution Comments: Santa Cruz and San Cristobal Islands. In Floreana Island was recorded a fossil

Author: (Palisot de Beauvois, 1796)
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Atalapha cinereus Peters, 1871, Nycteris cinereus Borkhausen, 1797
Distribution Comments: Present on Santa Cruz, San Cristobal, Floreana, Isabela and Santiago Islands

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Distribution Comments: No recent records, but previously recorded Santa Cruz; still present on San Cristobal (feral and domestic) on farmis in the transition zone
English Comments: It was recorded in 1989 on Santa Cruz Island in the farms. No records in the wild. Recorded (feral and domestic) in Transition zone - farms - in 2012.
Spanish Comments: Este individuo fue registrado en la isla de Santa Cruz en las fincas. No hubo registro de animales ferales. Registro en San Cristobal de individuos ferales y en granjas (Zona de transicion) registrados en 2012.

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Distribution Comments: Present on Floreana, San Cristobal, Isabela and Santa Cruz.
English Comments: The first record was in Floreana in 1832 and 1834, San Cristobal in 1847, Isabela in 1897 and later in Santa Cruz with the colonization. Also, in 1875 was introduced in Santiago, but eradicated in 2004 the feral animals.
Spanish Comments: La introduccion en Floreana fue en 1832 y 1834, en San Cristobal en 1847, en Isabela Sur en 1897 y posteriormente en Santa Cruz con la colonizacion. En 1875 fue en Santiago, pero erradicado como feral en 2004.
English Description: 'The donkey resembles a small, brown-grey horse with a large head, long ears and a long straight tail. Feral donkeys live in small groups that contain a dominant male and 3-4 females, or in bachelor groups.
Spanish Description: El burro se asemeja a un caballo pequeño de café-gris con una cabeza grande, orejas largas y una cola larga y recta. Los burros salvajes viven en pequeños grupos, con un macho dominante y 3-4 unas hembras. También existen grupos de solteros. La hembra produce una cría por año. Los burros son capaces de comer vegetación muy gruesa en las zonas con poca agua.

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Distribution Comments: Present on Santa Cruz, Isabela, San Cristobal and Floreana

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Distribution Comments: Intercepted on San Cristobal Island.

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Distribution Comments: Established populations are restricted to towns on Santa Cruz, San Cristobal, Isabela, and Floreana. 170,000 tourists visit the archipelago per year.
English Comments: The human is a large omnivorous bipedal ape, with an enlarged brain case.  A communal, highly adaptable and intelligent species, it is normally monogamous with 1-7 children per pair.
English Description: The human is a large omnivorous bipedal ape, with an enlarged brain case.  A communal, highly adaptable and intelligent species.
Spanish Description: El ser humano es un gran simio omnívoros bípedos, con un cerebro amplio. Una especie que vive en comunidad, altamente adaptable e inteligente, normalmente es monógama, con 1-7 hijos por pareja.

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Distribution Comments: Present on Santa Cruz, San Cristobal and Isabela
English Comments: The first record was in 1984 in the farming area in Santa Cruz Island, San Cristobal and Islabela. No recorded in wildlife. The present population status is unknow.
Spanish Comments: El primer registro fue en 1984 en la zona de fincas en la Isla Santa Cruz, San Cristobal e Isabela. No existen individuos en estado silvestre. Se desconoce el estado poblacional en la actualidad.

Author: (Allen, 1892)
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Oryzomys galapagoensis bauri (Allen, 1892) [previous versions of the checklist erroneoulsy cited this synonym as Oryzomys galapagoensis bauri Wilson & Reeder, 2005, but this name does not exist, instead the species is listed in Wilson & Reeder (2005) who did not publish that name]; Oryzomys bauri Allen, 1892
Distribution Comments: Present only in Santa Fe Island.

Author: (Waterhouse, 1839)
Taxonomic Comments: Syn.: Oryzomys galapagoensis (Waterhouse, 1839), Oryzomys galapagoensis galapagoensis Waterhouse, 1839
Distribution Comments: Extinct in Galapagos, was present in San Cristobal Island.

Author: Niethammer, 1964
English Common Name: Santa Cruz and Isabela Galapagos rat, giant Galápagos rice rat
Spanish Common Name: Rata gigante de Santa Cruz e Isabela
Distribution Comments: It was present in Santa Cruz Island
It was present in Isabela Island

Author: (Linnaeus, 1758)
Distribution Comments: Santa Cruz, San Cristobal, Floreana, Isabela, Baltra, Santiago, Plaza Sur(?), originally from Central Asia.
English Comments: This species arrived in Galapagos with human colonization, possibly when a ship run aground off the coast.
Spanish Comments: Posiblemente hubo la introduccion de esta especie al colonizar las islas o al encallar un barco en las costas de las mismas.
English Description: The house mouse is a small rodent, 7 to 10 cm long with a tail much longer than its body. It is often associated with humans. Mice are very territorial, and dominant males are aggressive towards other males.
Spanish Description: El ratón doméstico es un pequeño roedor, 7 a 10 cm de largo con una cola mucho más larga que su cuerpo. A menudo se asocia con los seres humanos. Es un omnívoro nocturno, pero prefiere las semillas. Las hembras pueden reproducirse a partir de 6 semanas de edad con 8 camadas por año cada uno que contienen por lo general 6 crias. Los ratones machos son muy territoriales, agresivos y dominantes frente a otros machos.

Author: Osgood, 1929
Distribution Comments: It was present in Santa Cruz Island, and the last collected was in 1930

Author: Hutterer & Hirsch, 1979
English Common Name: Fernandina Galapagos mouse, Darwin's rice rat
Distribution Comments: Present in Fernandina Island

Author: (Thomas, 1899)
Distribution Comments: It was present in Santa Cruz and Baltra Islands. The last collected were in 1934 and 1929 respectively.

Author: Heller, 1904
Distribution Comments: Present in Fernandina Island
It was present in Rabida Island
It was present in Isabela Island
It was present in Isabela Island

Author: Orr, 1938
Distribution Comments: Present in Santiago Island.

Author: Berkenhout, 1769
Distribution Comments: Santa Cruz, San Cristóbal, Islabela, Floreana, Baltra, Rábida, Santiago.
English Comments: A long slender bodied rodent, greyish-brown in colour with a tail of equal length to its body. Adults live for approximately one year. They are omnivores and will eat almost anything, mostly active at night. However they are not good climbers, and are usually found associated with humans.
English Description: A large, thickset rat with a long, nearly hairless tail of length equal to or less than the length of its body and relatively small, hairless ears. Coloration is brown on the back and pale gray on the belly.
Spanish Description: Un roedor de cuerpo largo delgado, de color marrón grisáceo, con una cola de longitud igual a su cuerpo. Los adultos viven durante aproximadamente un año. Son omnívoros y comen casi cualquier cosa, en su mayoría activos durante la noche. Sin embargo, no son buenos escaladores, y se encuentran generalmente asociados con los seres humanos.

Author: Linnaeus, 1758
Distribution Comments: Widespread in the archipelago. Present on Santa Cruz, San Cristóbal, Floreana, Isabela, Baltra, Santiago, Pinzón, Bartolome(?). Eradicated on Bainbridge and Seymour Norte?
English Comments: This species arrived in Galapagos with human colonization, possibly when a ship run aground off the coast.
Spanish Comments: Posiblemente hubo la introduccion de esta especie al colonizar las islas o al encallar un barco en las costas de las mismas.
English Description: A slender and darkly-colored rat with a largely hairless tail that is longer than the body and large, hairless ears. It is smaller than the brown rat and much more agile, with the ability to climb trees. Coloration varies from uniformly black to gray-brown, or gray-brown with a creamy-white belly.
Spanish Description: La rata negra es delgada, y negruzco, con una cola más larga que el cuerpo. Es más pequeño que la rata marrón y muy ágil, capaz de subir a los árboles. Este roedor es un omnívoro oportunista nocturna y se encuentra lejos de los seres humanos.
